questiontext.text:
Exercise


For the function \(f(x) = {@f@}\), \({@x1@} \leq x \leq {@x2@} \), find the positions of any local minima or maxima and distinguish between them.


  1. Calculate the first derivative, \(\dfrac{\mathrm{d}f}{\mathrm{d}x}=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]
    [[feedback:prt1]]
  2. The stationary points are located at: \(x = \) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] (write your answer as a list, e.g. [x1,x2,x3])
    [[feedback:prt2]]
  3. Now calculate the second derivative \(\displaystyle \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^2f}{\mathrm{d}x^2}=\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]
    [[feedback:prt3]]

  4. Finally, evaluate the second derivative at each stationary point and draw appropriate conclusions:

    \(\quad\) At \(x=\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]], \(\dfrac{\mathrm{d}^2f}{\mathrm{d}x^2}=\) [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]]. Hence, this is a [[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]]

    \(\quad\) At \(x=\) [[input:ans7]] [[validation:ans7]], \(\dfrac{\mathrm{d}^2f}{\mathrm{d}x^2}=\) [[input:ans8]] [[validation:ans8]]. Hence, this is a [[input:ans9]] [[validation:ans9]]

    \(\quad\) At \(x=\) [[input:ans10]] [[validation:ans10]], \(\dfrac{\mathrm{d}^2f}{\mathrm{d}x^2}=\) [[input:ans11]] [[validation:ans11]]. Hence, this is a [[input:ans12]] [[validation:ans12]]
    [[feedback:prt4]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. For \(f(x)={@f@}\) we have \[\frac{\mathrm{d}f}{\mathrm{d}x}={@df@}.\]

  2. Hence stationary points are at values of \(x\) in the range specified for which \({@realroots(df)[1]@}\), i.e. at \({@const*x@} = \pi\) or \({@const*x@} = 2\pi\) or \({@const*x@} = 3\pi\) (making sure \(x\) is within the range \({@x1@} \leq x \leq {@x2@}\)). Then, stationary points are located at \(x=\displaystyle {@extrema[1]@}\), \(x= \displaystyle {@extrema[2]@}\) and \(x=\displaystyle {@extrema[3]@}\).

  3. For the second derivative we have \[\frac{\mathrm{d}^2f}{\mathrm{d}x^2} = {@d2f@}.\]

  4. So, we have \[\begin{align} &\frac{\mathrm{d}^2f}{\mathrm{d}x^2}\Bigr|_{x= {@extrema[1]@}} &=& {@ta_diff[1]@}\\ &\frac{\mathrm{d}^2f}{\mathrm{d}x^2}\Bigr|_{x= {@extrema[2]@}} &=& {@ta_diff[2]@}\\ &\frac{\mathrm{d}^2f}{\mathrm{d}x^2}\Bigr|_{x= {@extrema[3]@}} &=& {@ta_diff[3]@} \end{align}\]


    Hence, \(x=\displaystyle {@extrema[1]@}\) is a {@class1@}, \(x= \displaystyle {@extrema[2]@}\) is a {@class2@}, and \(x=\displaystyle {@extrema[3]@}\) is a {@class3@}.


    You can check against a sketch:

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

falsefeedback.text: \(x= {@sa1[1]@}\) does not locate a stationary point of {@f@}.
\(\frac{d^2 f}{dx^2}\) is not well calculated for \(x={@sa1[1]@}\).

truefeedback.text: \(x={@sa3[1]@}\) has been repeated.

falsefeedback.text: \(x= {@sa2[1]@}\) does not locate a stationary point of {@f@}.
\(\frac{d^2 f}{dx^2}\) is not well calculated for \(x={@sa2[1]@}\).
\(x= {@sa3[1]@}\) does not locate a stationary point of {@f@}.
\(\frac{d^2 f}{dx^2}\) is not well calculated for \(x={@sa3[1]@}\).
\(x={@sa2[1]@}\) has been repeated.
